descriptionSet.description: In this poster from the Empire Calender Manufacturing Co. Calcutta several workers can be seen plucking tea leaves in a tea plantation with baskets hanging from their hands to collect the leaves. Behind the plantation are several houses and hills. To the left of the image, a woman dressed in a sari and wearing lots of jewellery can be seen holding a cup and saucer of steaming tea. To the right of the image a woman dressed in simple clothes carries a tray with a cups and saucers and containers for sugar, cream and milk all ready to be served.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

hra:item.hra:value: Das, Sushil
text-en: Sushil Das..
text-en: No. 386 Tea Garden

description-en: In this poster from the Empire Calender Manufacturing Co. Calcutta several workers can be seen plucking tea leaves in a tea plantation with baskets hanging from their hands to collect the leaves. Behind the plantation are several houses and hills. To the left of the image, a woman dressed in a sari and wearing lots of jewellery can be seen holding a cup and saucer of steaming tea. To the right of the image a woman dressed in simple clothes carries a tray with a cups and saucers and containers for sugar, cream and milk all ready to be served. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The most dramatic expansion of tea consumption—and the development of relatively standardized chai (produced by boiling tea leaves in a mixture of milk, water, and sugar, with optional spices such as cardamom, cinnamon, clove, ginger, or black pepper)—only occurred after 1947 and the ensuing transfer of majority ownership in tea estates (which, significantly, were exempted from the sweeping land-reform legislation of the Nehru-Congress era) and in tea wholesaling companies from British to Indian hands. This shift is exemplified in this image, which recapitulates the popular visual trope of "the journey of tea" from tea-garden to consumer. (Philip Lutgendorf)(gs)
